keqe_expansions: Diabetics should monitor their pulses regularly to ensure optimal health and proper management of their condition. Checking your pulse can provide important insights into your heart rate and overall cardiovascular health, which is especially vital for individuals with diabetes who may be at higher risk for heart-related complications. By regularly measuring your pulse, diabetics can track changes, detect irregularities, and alert their healthcare provider if any concerning patterns arise. Monitoring your pulse is a simple and effective way to stay proactive in managing your health and preventing potential complications associated with diabetes.

Diabetics should take their pulses regularly as part of monitoring their overall health and well-being. Monitoring pulse rate can provide important insights into cardiovascular health and help diabetics detect any potential issues early on. It is especially crucial for diabetics to be proactive in monitoring their pulses due to the increased risk of heart disease and other related complications associated with diabetes. By being vigilant about tracking their pulse rates, diabetics can better manage their condition and take necessary steps to maintain a healthy heart.

Chickpea (Cicer arietinum L.) is an important pulse crop grown and consumed all over the world, especially in the Afro-Asian countries. It is a good source of carbohydrates and protein, and protein quality is considered to be better than other pulses. Chickpea has significant amounts of all the essential amino acids except sulphur-containing amino acids, which can be complemented by adding cereals to the daily diet. Patients' attitudes to rectal drug administration.	One hundred adult patients attending for day case surgery were surveyed by anonymous questionnaire in order to determine their attitudes to rectal drug administration. Fifty four patients did not want an analgesic drug (diclofenac sodium) administered rectally whilst under anaesthesia, all preferring to take it orally if available. Ninety eight patients thought that drugs administered per rectum should always be discussed with them beforehand and a few had very strong feelings about this route of administration.
